A total amount of 472,374 gallons of oily water were hauled off by Environmental Remedies. Per the waste profile, coolant makes up 1% of the total amount of oily water. Data Quality Alert 1:The coolant that contains ethylene glycol is stored in tanks and utilized in closed-loop systems. As a result, there are no stack or point air emissions from it's usage. An amount has been calculated and included in this report for any ethylene glycol that is lost/evaporated inside of the storage tanks.Data Quality Alert 2: A different system/method was utilized to calculate the amount of emissions that are lost while the ethylene glycol is inside of the storage tanks. 33805LPHRS4620N	1312210298663	000100425	STYRENE	TRI	2012	AOC LLC	4620 N GALLOWAY RD	LAKELAND	POLK	FL	33810	YES	NO	NO	NO								325211						28.10083	-82.00971	876314329								THE ALPHA CORP	007037765	The reduction in emissions is due to the fact that we re-evaluated how we calculate emissions for the facility as a whole and refined the calcuations by using AP-42 published emission factors.  It was discovered that we were over estimating the emissions for styrene.  Using the published emission factors and current production and use information we refined the emissions calculation to provide a more realistic calculation of styrene emissions.Another change in the reporting category of the styrene emissions is from a change in vendor.  We send our used drums that contain a resin residue in the bottom to a drum recycler for reconditioning and resale.  The off-site transfer of resin is a calculation of the % styrene in the resin residue in the bottom of the drums sent to the recycler.  This vendor provided us with an accurate count of the number of drums.	NO	MDIEHL@AOC-RESINS.COM			NO

33805LPHRS4620N	1312210298612	000107211	ETHYLENE GLYCOL	TRI	2012	AOC LLC	4620 N GALLOWAY RD	LAKELAND	POLK	FL	33810	YES	NO	NO	NO								325211						28.10083	-82.00971	876314329								THE ALPHA CORP	007037765	Emission factors for all major chemicals at the plant were recalculated in 2012 using AP-42 published emission factors.  This resulted in a better estimation of point source and fugutive emissions for ethylene glycol.  However, the reported increase in glycol emissions is due to a higher estimate of fugitive emissions from the piping systems.  These calculations assume the piping is filled 8,760 hrs. per year when in fact it is not.  But the recording keeping to determine when there is actual EG in the piping system is too onerous, so the emissions are over-inflated.  All EG at the facility is used in the process and does not generate any waste streams.	NO	MDIEHL@AOC-RESINS.COM			NO

47987MSTRG1200E	1312210399426	N495	NICKEL COMPOUNDS	TRI	2012	MASTER GUARD CORP	1200 E 8TH ST	VEEDERSBURG	FOUNTAIN	IN	47987	YES	NO	NO	NO								336399						40.117151	-87.244974	556464444								FLEX-N-GATE CORP	011298072	The 2012 report shows an increase in the releases of nickel.  This increase is shown because the plant chose to report this value as a range instead of an exact number.  The TRI program converted a range into a value.  In 2011, the site reported emissions of 17.63 lbs .  In 2012, the site reported a range of 11-499 lbs in sections 5.1 and 5.2.  The TRI program converted each of these to 250 lbs each, and showed a release of 500 lbs vs 17.63.  This increase is due to reporting the values as a range instead of as a specific value. Univar USA has implemented pollution prevention practices to minimize the amount of self-generated waste and is committed to environmental stewardship.	NO	TIEN.PHAM@UNIVARUSA.COM			NO

This program endeavors to use the talents of our batch compounders and chemical formulators to develop new, more appropriate recipes for batches in an effort to successfully complete the batch without further processing.  Increasing the ¿first time right¿ percentage reduces waste, energy use, and reduces the use of other resources.  Over the last 4 years the Dap Tip City facility has increased the number of batches that have been successfully completed as first time right (FTR) .  These percentages are:  						CY09		76.67% 				CY10		80.71% 				CY11		82.02% 				CY12		86.55% As you can see, we have raised the average number of FTR batches by 10%.  In CY12, we made many more batches than in CY09, and yet, we are able to increase the FTR percentage.	NO	TDEVAULT@DAP.COM			NO

53004CDRVL3115J	1312209896911	N511	NITRATE COMPOUNDS	TRI	2012	CEDAR VALLEY CHEESE	W3111 JAY RD	BELGIUM	OZAUKEE	WI	53004	YES	NO	NO	NO								311513						43.5277	-87.94198											For 2012, based on information contained in Form R error messages, assumed nitrates transferred to POTWs were not treated by the POTWs; therefore, nitrates were reported as released to the environment.  This may have inadvertently not been reported in this manner for previous years, although the wastewater was transferred to the same POTWs and contained nitrates as in 2012.   We do not anticipate the need to transfer a significant amount of nitrate-containing wastewater to POTWs in future years due to construction of additional on-site wastewater storage.   This additional on-site storage will provide sufficient over-winter storage capacity to allow for spray-irrigation (land treatment) of most, if not all, of nitrate-containing wastewater for future years.    Wastewater containing nitrates was spray-irrigated on agricultural fields (land treatment).   Since this is a release of nitrates to the soils, this was reported as a release of nitrates to the environment.   However,  the soils and plants treat nitrates at a very high efficiency. 63701LNSTR2524S	1312210129134	N090	CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS(EXCEPT CHROMITE ORE MINED IN THE TRANSVAAL REGION)	TRI	2012	BUZZI UNICEM USA - CAPE GIRARDEAU	2524 S SPRIGG ST	CAPE GIRARDEAU	CAPE GIRARDEAU	MO	63701	YES	NO	NO	NO								327310						37.2676	-89.5385	063778211								BUZZI UNICEM USA	611764820	Per Section 4 of 1998 EPCRA Section 313 Questions and Answers guidance document . The Section 313 chemicals in scrap metal we send offsite for recycling is not being reported as had been done in previous years.588. If a covered facility sends metal scraps containing chromium off-siteto be remelted and subsequently reused, does it report the amount oftoxic chemical in the metal as recycled off-site?Assuming no contaminants are removed during the melting process, thechromium in the metal scraps is not actually being recovered but merelymelted and reused. Therefore, the amount of the toxic chemical in the metalscraps would not be reportable in Part II, Sections 6.2 or 8 of the Form R.However, because the facility is repackaging and distributing the toxicchemicals in commerce, it should consider these amounts of the toxicchemical towards the facility¿s processing threshold. If the covered facilityexceeds a chemical activity threshold, it is required to file a TRI Report forthat chemical.	NO	STEVEN.LEUS@BUZZIUNICEMUSA.COM			YES

91355RMNC 28101	1312210277950	N120	DIISOCYANATES	TRI	2012	REMO INC	28101 INDUSTRY DR	VALENCIA	LOS ANGELES	CA	913554102	YES	NO	NO	NO								339992						34.44963	-118.62739											As the contents of the isocyanate and the pylol in the drums reach the emptying levels bubbling or foaming is created from the action of their individual transfer pumps. In the past we had no choice but to allow the remaining portions of those chemicals in the drums to go to waste instead of using them.Last December 2012 it was figured that if individual holding tanks that are bigger than 55 gallons are provided then the contents of the new drums can immediately transferred there as soon as production receives them.that in effect will allow the bubbles/foam to float to the top and eventually pop out after sometime. this action will lead to a reduction of our waste coming from these streams and also save us some money. by the next or the year after we may again start using form A to report on the isocyanates	NO	MALCANTARA@REMO.COM			NO

77830GBBNS25MIL	1312210478994	N420	LEAD COMPOUNDS	PBT	2012	GIBBONS CREEK STEAM ELECTRIC STATION	12824 FM 244	ANDERSON	GRIMES	TX	778305642	YES	NO	NO	NO								221112						30.619651	-96.081834	071374052										There are two primary reasons for the significant decline in TMPA's emissions, 2012 versus 2011.  First TMPA did not operate at all for nearly four months in 2012 and was operating at a very reduced level for much of the time that we were operating.  Second in 2011 TMPA operated with a roughly even mix of coal shipments from three different mines.  Beginning in 2013 TMPA will exclusively use coal from one mine.  2012 was a transition year with one mine accounting for roughly 70% of the coal and other two dividing the rest.  Coal from the different mines contains differing amounts of trace elements and so TMPA's emissions are shifted.	NO	JHORBACZEWSKI@TEXASMPA.ORG			YES

Reason: The 2011 reporting year shows the Batch and Continuous plants were both in operation.  The Batch plant ran for 20.7 weeks and the Continuous plant ran for 17.1 weeks for a combined totalof 38 weeks.  Both plants processed a combined total of 17252606 lb's of raw wheat germ.  The current 2012 production year shows that the Continuous plant ran only for 1.4 weeks and the Batch plant ran for 32.4 weeks.  Both plants processed a total of 13218234 lb's of raw wheat germ which is 4034372 lb's less than the previous 2011 year.  The reason for the reduction between the 2011 and 2012 reporting years was the difficulty in procuring the necessary quantities of raw wheat germ.   In addition, our out look for the 2013 reporting year is going to be about the same as the 2012 unless we are able to secure additional quantities of raw wheat germ needed.Note:  The above information and reason also applies to the other two Quality Alerts. 77630CHVRNFM100	1312210134235	000074851	ETHYLENE	TRI	2012	CHEVRON PHILLIPS CHEMICAL CO LP - ORANGE	5309 FM 1006	ORANGE	ORANGE	TX	77630	YES	NO	NO	NO								325211						30.0475	-93.779166	152975665								CHEVRON PHILLIPS CHEMICAL CO LLC	152975665	Most of the decrease in VOC emissions in RY2011 comes from EPN: 58, which is the flare.  In 2011 Flare emissions were calculated using a plant-wide material balance that uses information from several mass flowmeters located in the process units.  Currently there is no mass flowmeter on the total flare header.  Therefore, the calculations had to rely on information from several other mass flowmeters instead of one mass flow meter on the flare header.  Incoming ethylene is approximately 900 MMlbs/yr. A Â±1.0% error in the material balance could correlate to a Â±9 MMlbs/yr change in the ethylene balance.  This means a Â±0.2% error in the material balance could result in an emissions increase or decrease of 10 TPY.  CP Chem is currently implementing a project where a new mass flowmeter is being installed on the total flare header.  Installation of this flowmeter results in more accurate estimations of emissions in future EI submittals.	NO	PRITCML@CPCHEM.COM			NO

Per conversation with EPA hotline, a site organic wastestream sent to incineration contains trace copper compounds.  While the off-site incineration does not treat the copper compounds, ash from the incinerator, including the copper compounds, would ultimately be landfilled.  To resolve how to report this off-site transfer to a treatment facility, EPA hotline suggested to document the amount of copper compound in the organic waste sent to incineration by use the M94 "transfer to broker - disposal" code as the waste transfer did occur to the incinerator, however the site does not know where the incinerator ash, potentially contaiminated with the copper compounds, would be landfilled. 02703LCHGR49PEA	1312210239303	007697372	NITRIC ACID	TRI	2012	LEACHGARNER	49 PEARL ST	ATTLEBORO	BRISTOL	MA	02703	YES	NO	NO	NO								331491	339911					41.940287	-71.278789	001208933								LEACHGARNER	001208933	In previous years the nitric acid etch process was use to etch copper clad precious metal jewelry findings, balls, and beads in order to remove copper cladding from the near finished parts.  There was a significant amount of copper clad precious metal left from the manufacturing process that was sent off site to refineries for precious metal recovery.  The costs associated with refining and the additional time that the gold was tied up in the recovery process was very expensive.  In the second quarter of 2011 the company, in order to reduce processing refining cost, had started to it etch high grade copper clad metal in house that typically would have been sent off site and refined in order to remove the copper.  The gold recovery was in full operation in 2012.  The associated refinery costs were eliminated for that precious metals recovery stream and the recovery time of the precious metal was reduced to where the etch precious could be remelted in place back into the production process at a great cost savings.It was due to the precious metal recovery in addition to the routinely etched findings, balls, and beads that the company had a large increase in the production ratio for this particular process.	NO	RDUBUC@LEACHGARNER.COM			NO

95231MNRNC9508S	1312210318857	007439921	LEAD	TRI	2012	BORAL ROOFING LLC	9508 S HARLAN RD	FRENCH CAMP	SAN JOAQUIN	CA	95231	YES	NO	NO	NO								327390						37.865403	-121.278777	026389254								BORAL INDUSTRIES INC	026389254	Our company has been implemented several new programs that have made a great improvement in our overall performance going from safety to environmental. We have gone over 2,000 days without a lost time incident. A near-miss reporting program has been implemented which not only focuses on safety, but on identifying environmental issues as well. Employees are expected to report 1-2 minimum monthly issues. A 5 "S" program has been implemented and maintained where all stored wastes have been identified and removed. Areas maintained organized and clean at all times. A Material Control program was also introduced where just enough material is ordered to avoid overstocking and prevent shortages. This aids in overstocking and exceeding materials shelf life generating waste. It optimizes storage space and makes our 5 S program successful.  One of the most impacting programs implemented and which has provided most waste reduction results has been our LEAN program which has helped in waste reduction. This programs is aimed at optimizing our processes by performing root cause analyses on identified issues. Our reject percentage has decreased and our overall manufacturing efficiencies improved.	NO	JESUS.ESPINOZA@BORAL.COM			YES

97321SLMTN33992	1312210800595	007664393	HYDROGEN FLUORIDE	TRI	2012	SELMET INC	33992 SEVEN MILE LN SE.	ALBANY	LINN	OR	973227240	YES	NO	NO	NO								331528						44.584398	-123.060698	077966869										Selmet has built a new, efficient, and highly monitored chemical milling facility which increases safety and minimizes unnecessary dragout, as well as a plethora of other safety and environmental improvements. In addition, a wastewater treatment plant performing elementary neutralization has also been built. It is anticipated that these will be fully operational in October of 2013.Selmet's TRI was 2 screens from being completed, validated, and sent out for review before being certified on Thurs. Jun. 27th 2013, when Peter Magolske and Kevin Schanilec from EPA Region 10 showed up on the morning of 6/27 to do a routine inspection along with Susan Shewczyk from Oregon DEQ. It was not immediately on their radar that the TRI report was due for facilities. The inspection took until after 5:00 p.m. with me having to do another 5 hours of follow up on pulling, scanning, and emailing documentation so that the inspectors wouldn't have to return for a second day to look at more records. By the time I returned to the TRI report on Friday afternoon, it was already having problems timing out every 30 seconds. I had other important appointments and activities that could not be rescheduled, plus the TRI still needed to be reviewed by key personnel who were unavailable. I could not log in over the weekend. Monday the whole TRI-web system was down. I contacted Sandy at the CDX hotline and she put me on an email list to be notified when the system would be back up. I waited until 6:30 PST for the email which hadn't arrived yet and still I could not log in.|PRAI:Metal Melted to pour parts is a direct production variable to determine what the throughput is to Chem Mill|TPRL:Slipped a digit in last years reporting of HF waste pounds, which was not caught in peer and management review or by the validation step. It has been corrected in this years report.	NO	GREGS@SELMETINC.COM			NO

By the time I returned to the TRI report on Friday afternoon, it was already having problems timing out every 30 seconds. 02134GNZYM500SO	1312210685778	000107211	ETHYLENE GLYCOL	TRI	2012	GENZYME CORP	500 SOLDIERS FIELD RD	ALLSTON	SUFFOLK	MA	02134	YES	NO	NO	NO								325412						42.358271	-71.118345	025322127								GENZYME CORP		The site measures production ratio by the amount of protein generated. In previous years there were two products "Fz" and "Cz"(same production unit) that use the protein as their active ingredient made at the site. In early 2012 one of the products "Fz" manufactured at the site was transferred to another site to make room for increased manufacturing and processing of the less protein requiring product "Cz".The product removed from the site "Fz" required more protein as the active ingredient thus the decrease in production ratio.However there was no decrease in the amount of ethylene glycol realized because the part of the manufacturing process which uses ethylene glicol is a common process for both products. With the removal of one product, it allowed for increased processing of the other, thus negating any reduction of the ethylene glycol used.	NO	AMY.ATWOOD@GENZYME.COM			NO

TOWERS RD BLDG 3560	PENSACOLA	ESCAMBIA	FL	32508	YES	NO	YES	NO								928110						30.35722	-87.28305									US DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE		Please note: Documentation was provided that indicates that 34,006 pounds of soil material was removed from the firing range berm and transferred to Whiting Metals, LLC in Whiting, Indiana.  A berm sample was collected for laboratory analysis for Toxicity Characteristic Leaching Procedure (TCLP) for Lead using EPA Method 6010B.  The analytical results indicated that the berm was impacted by lead from it's use as a firing range.  The following assumptions were made regarding the waste removed from the berm: the weight of the soil removed was 34,006 pounds, and the soil contained approximately 10% lead (by weight).  Based on these assumptions, approximately 3,401 pounds of lead was contained in the waste transferred off site to Whiting Metals, LLC for proper disposal.	YES	HARRY.WHITE@NAVY.MIL			YES

Discussions with senior technical managers indicated that we should reduce the EF by a factor of 1,000 based on the glass reflow temperature, which is significantly lower than a glass "manufacturing" temperature, and leads to a much lower vapor pressure (tendency to off-gas) of the lead compound being reflowed. 38478MRMNTBENNE	1312210498212	N090	CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS(EXCEPT CHROMITE ORE MINED IN THE TRANSVAAL REGION)	TRI	2012	MAGNETI MARELLI SUSPENSIONS USA	181 BENNETT DR	PULASKI	GILES	TN	38478	YES	NO	NO	NO								336330						35.20661	-87.06133	832898469										The amount of  toxic substance (Chromium) represented in this report is greater than the previous year while the production shows a decrease. The production mix changed dramatically in 2012 from 2011.Explanation: The major contributor to the facility release is chrome bearing sludge generated by pretreatment of waste water from chrome plating activities. The production of parts for chrome plating was drastically decreased  while production of other parts that generated waste water increased significantly. The more waste water to be treated, the more sludge that is generated. It is then conceivable that the content of the chrome in the sludge is considerably less that the factor used to calculate the totals for this report. However, the quantities used were on the basis of the most recent information available. The facility would like to reserve the right re-evaluate the waste for content and make ammendments to this report at a later date.	NO	DON.GIBSON@MAGNETIMARELLI.COM			YES

29223FNMNF797CL	1312210144198	007439921	LEAD	TRI	2012	FN MANUFACTURING LLC	797 OLD CLEMSON RD	COLUMBIA	RICHLAND	SC	29229	YES	NO	NO	NO								332994						34.124755	-80.870265	098401086										FN produces two kinds of waste lead: lead and gravel from our firing range, and lead dust from the filtration system attached to the firing range. 29223FNMNF797CL	1312210144186	007440473	CHROMIUM	TRI	2012	FN MANUFACTURING LLC	797 OLD CLEMSON RD	COLUMBIA	RICHLAND	SC	29229	YES	NO	NO	NO								332994						34.124755	-80.870265	098401086										Many of the previous years' submissions took the worst case scenario in assuming that all of FN's chromium related releases were "chromium metals." However, after review, it was determined that this worst case scenario is no longer applicable as one of the streams that was reported in the past can be considered "chromium compounds" and is therefore not reportable under "chromium metals." It is for the above reason that FN reported 7,500 pounds in RY2011 and is reporting 0.45 pounds in 2012.Another irregularity to be noted is that from RY2011 to RY 2012, FN's production related waste increased from 12,922 pounds to 26,921 pounds of chromium. This chromium is a component of stainless steel, and stainless steel is a material very commonly used to make pistol barrels and pistol slides. FN's commercial gun business has been on the increase for a while and exploded in RY2012. It is to be noted that we produce more pistols in one month now (CY2013) than we did in any year prior to RY2011. As such, this increase in waste generation comes at no surprise to us.	NO				YES	 	
29223FNMNF797CL	1312210144200	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	FN MANUFACTURING LLC	797 OLD CLEMSON RD	COLUMBIA	RICHLAND	SC	29229	YES	NO	NO	NO								332994						34.124755	-80.870265	098401086										There is a substantial difference between the values reported for RY2012 and RY 2011. There are two primary reasons for this difference.1) Production has been down, so FN's activity index is 0.695. However, this alone does not explain the large difference between the reported emissions in RY2011 and RY2012.2) In previous years, FN calculated emissions through the use of mass balances. However, this mass balance is somewhat inaccurate, as explained below.										a) On top of FN's methanol storage tank is a dial that displays the tank level. Using the cross sectional area of the tank and the density of methanol, we calculated the volume consumed.								b) The methanol tank also has a flow meter that records all methanol used. The discrepancy between the drop in tank level and the value recorded by the flow meter was taken as the emissions for that time period. For example, let's say on Monday, the tank level was 8' 6" and on Tuesday, the level was 8' 1". This indicates a drop in liquid level of 5". Let's say that this drop amounts to 50 gallons. Now, let's say the flow meter recorded that only 49 gallons were actually used. How do we account for the 1 gallon discrepancy? That 1 gallon would be considered as methanol emissions.											c) There is a small problem with the method outlined in (b). Humans of different heights reading the tank dial from different angles can record inconsistent tank levels. This discrepancy can be as much as 2". In this tank, 2" can be the equivalent of gallons. This discrepancy can lead to inaccurate tank level calculations, which can lead to substantial differences between the volume calculated from the tank and the actual volume used as recorded by the flow meter.										d) In response to this issue, FN is now using emission factors calculated by the EPA's TANKS Simulator. These values are less than what we have been reporting prior to RY2012, and we believe them to be more accurate.	NO				NO

As a result, the values for on-site energy recovery and off-site disposal have changed significantly from RY 2011 to RY 2012.  Also note:  Submission of TRI data delayed by EPA server access issues. 60110MCWHR400EA	1312210558476	001330207	XYLENE (MIXED ISOMERS)	TRI	2012	PCCR USA INC	99 E COTTAGE AVE	CARPENTERSVILLE	KANE	IL	60110	YES	NO	NO	NO								325211						42.116425	-88.289281	968259981										This facility is regulated under the MON Standard for fugitive emissions.  As such, the facility maintains a formal tagging, monitoring and data logging program. During this past year  (2012), the software company that the facility utilizes (LeakDas), issued an   updated their data logging software.  The new version applies an average emission rate, that are recorded for required component monitoring, and applies these average emission rates, to the components that are exempt from monitoring requirements or that may be on a far less frequently monitored schedule. It should also be noted that the software automatically escalates the average emissions values on an annual basis for non monitored components, This has resulted in what would appear to be a significantly inflated fugitive emissions component in this annual report.  PCCR is in the process of implementing a very extensive monitoring program to collect actual leak data, that will assist in the development of a more actual/realistic determination of potential fugitive emissions at the facility.	NO	MARTY.GUDMUNDSON@PCCRUSA.COM			NO

42348CNTRY1627S	1312210253124	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2012	CENTURY ALUMINUM OF KENTUCKY	1627 STATE RT 3543	HAWESVILLE	HANCOCK	KY	423480500	YES	NO	NO	NO								331312						37.94499	-86.78777	054273909								CENTURY ALUMINUM CO INC	942268202	The facility address has changed due to the state of Kentucky changing the number of the highway from State Route 271 North to State Route 3543.  The facility has not changed locations.Section 5.1 Fugitive or Non-point Air Emisssions & Section 5.2 Stack or Point Air Emissions --  The increases in onsite air releases of PACs is due to more accurate data for air emissions obtained from new sampling test for POM releases from Century's potline roofs and stacks.  The new data was developed due to a Section 114 ICR (Information Collection Request) from EPA.  In previous years emission factors developed during studies conducted for the Primary Aluminum MACT Standard (40 CFR Part 63 Subpart LL) were used.  Using the new data and the percentage of PACs of the total POMs listed on the MSDS for Liquid Pitch the fugitive and stack releases were several hundred times higher. Also the emission rate for POMs at Century's carbon anode bake control device increased 91% due to data from a compliance test in 2012.  The control system was checked and repairs made to get POM emissions down.Section 7A On Site Waste Treatment -- There was a large decrease in the amount of PACs treated on site due to new data from air emissions compliance test for POM releases at Century's carbon anode bake facility.  In previous years an engineering estimate based on the amount of PACs entering the process was used to calculate the amount of PACs entering the anode bake emissions control devices.  The test data revealed that a much larger amount of the PACs is burned (destroyed) or converted during the baking process than the engeering estimate took into account.|TPRL:Section 7A On Site Waste Treatment -- There was a large decrease in the amount of PACs treated on site due to new data from air emissions compliance test for POM releases at Century's carbon anode bake facility. The new data was developed due to a Section 114 ICR (Information Collection Request) from EPA.  In previous years emission factors developed during studies conducted for the Primary Aluminum MACT Standard (40 CFR Part 63 Subpart LL) were used.  Using the new data and the percentage of Benzo(g,h,i)perylene of the total POMs listed on the MSDS for Liquid Pitch the fugitive and stack releases were several hundred times higher. Also the emission rate for POMs at Century's carbon anode bake control device increased 91% due to data from a compliance test in 2012.  The control system was checked and repairs made to get POM emissions down.Section 7A On Site Waste Treatment -- There was a large decrease in the amount of Benzo(g,h,i)perylene treated on site due to new data from air emissions compliance test for POM releases at Century's carbon anode bake facility.  In previous years an engineering estimate based on the amount of Benzo(g,h,i)perylene entering the process was used to calculate the amount of Benzo(g,h,i)perylene entering the anode bake emissions control devices.  The test data revealed that a much larger amount of the Benzo(g,h,i)perylene is burned (destroyed) or converted during the baking process than the engeering estimate took into account.   |TARL:Section 5.1 Fugitive or Non-point Air Emisssions & Section 5.2 Stack or Point Air Emissions --  The increases in onsite air releases of Benzo(g,h,i)perylene is due to more accurate data for air emissions obtained from new sampling test for POM releases from Century's potline roofs and stacks. 78250XYTRN8001M	1312210447544	N420	LEAD COMPOUNDS	PBT	2012	XYTRONICS LTD	8001 MAINLAND DR	SAN ANTONIO	BEXAR	TX	78250	YES	NO	NO	NO								334418						29.512538	-98.658059	151820164										This year the preparer received EPA sponsored TRI Reporting Training.  The training provided some needed clarification and guidance to specific elements of Form R reporting.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 The most significant change to the current Form R report is that of the chemical reported itself.  After receiving training it is clear that the chemical is best reported as N420 Lead Compounds and not (elemental) Lead.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Additionally, during the accounting of the maximum amount of Lead Compounds present on-site in section 4.1, a threshold-calculation assumption had been used in previous submissions.  After training this assumption has been removed, causing the range code to change from 02 to 03.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 New understanding of the definitions of Â¿ManufactureÂ¿, Â¿ProcessÂ¿, and Â¿Otherwise-UseÂ¿ show the previous use of the 'Import' designation is not the best way to report Lead Compounds.  This submission reflects the better reporting designation of 'Manufacture' and 'as a by-product'.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Lastly, yearly disposal of solder contaminated wastes has not been recognized in previous report submissions as an off-site transfer.  This current Form R submission has added this transfer appropriately in sections 6.2 and 8.1d.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Xytronics', good practices in handling Lead Compounds continue this year, as in previous years, where approximately .03% is released, 1.4% is properly disposed of and 98.6% of our chemical is recycled annually.  Our policies for recycling and proper disposal of this chemical were established many years ago, and this year our reporting has been updated to follow suit.	NO	LARRYGO@XYTRONICS.COM			YES

90280SHLTZ5321F	1312210064642	007440473	CHROMIUM	TRI	2012	SHULTZ STEEL CO	5321 E FIRESTONE BLVD	SOUTH GATE	LOS ANGELES	CA	90280	YES	NO	NO	NO								332111	332112					33.951482	-118.174885	009593567										The total weight for the metal dust generated during 2011 was 545.64 (1,091,280 lbs) whereas the corresponding amount for 2012 was 565.34 tons [(1,130,680 pounds (lbs)], an increase of only +3.6 percent (%). Although the generated volume for both years is similar, the actual amount of Chromium is calculated using the concentrations reported by the analytical laboratory for the metal dust samples collected each individual year. The 2011 measured Chromium concentrations were 1,222.5 micrograms/kilogram (mg/kg) or parts per million (ppm), whereas the 2012 concentrations ranged between 65 and 3,200 ppm. Consequently, the 2011 and 2012 estimated annual total amounts for Chromium vary significantly, 1,332 and 2,294 lbs, respectively (+72%). Despite the fact that the rough metal ingots were the same type and the volumes of generated metal dust were similar between both years. However, the measured concentrations for 2012 were higher.	NO	PJNASH@SHULTZSTEEL.COM			YES

63134LHBND8833F	1312210245496	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	LHB INDUSTRIES	8833 FLEISCHER PL	BERKELEY	ST LOUIS	MO	631341000	YES	NO	NO	NO								325510						38.758762	-90.339969	148052707								LIGHTHOUSE FOR THE BLIND	051731214	On 6-17-2013 I submitted a question via the TRI website about potential releases to the POTW and the affect on Section 8.1c (Ticket #23002-453584).  The response I received was an instruction to call the Information Center.  The staff member I spoke with worked diligently to address the issue but we were unable to resolve the zero vs. NA situation I was wanting to address. [Start New Paragraph]While it is extremely unlikely that the TRI chemicals at my facility will ever enter a drain there is still the potential for a discharge to the POTW.  So in section 6.1 I indicate the quantity transferred to the POTW as zero and indicated the basis of estimate as M2.  The POTW requires annual testing for organic compounds.  [Start New Paragraph]With a zero in section 6.1 TRI-MEweb indicates a zero for 8.1c "off-site disposal to Class I Underground Injection Wells, RCRA Subtitle C landfills, and other landfills."  I do not feel that is consistent with what is occurring.  There is no potential for my facility, nor does the POTW dispose of the chemical, via underground injection or a landfill.  The software should allow for an NA response in Sections 8.1c, 8.1d and 8.7 even if there is a potential for a discharge to the POTW.  [Start New Paragraph] Quite simply the possibility of a release to the POTW does not equate to a the possibility of a release to a underground injection well or landfill.	NO	CCRUSE@LHBINDUSTRIES.COM			NO

So in section 6.1 I indicate the quantity transferred to the POTW as zero and indicated the basis of estimate as M2.  The POTW requires annual testing for organic compounds. I do not feel that is consistent with what is occurring.  There is no potential for my facility, nor does the POTW dispose of the chemical, via underground injection or a landfill.  The software should allow for an NA response in Sections 8.1c, 8.1d and 8.7 even if there is a potential for a discharge to the POTW.[Start New Paragraph] Quite simply the possibility of a release to the POTW does not equate to a the possibility of a release to a underground injection well or landfill. 29678NGLHR554MO	1312210640456	007664939	SULFURIC ACID (1994 AND AFTER "ACID AEROSOLS" ONLY)	TRI	2012	BASF CORP	554 ENGELHARD DR	SENECA	OCONEE	SC	29678	YES	NO	NO	NO								325188						34.652142	-82.9552	157499179								BASF CORP	001307032	The BASF has ammonia and amine wet scrubbers that control ammonia/amine with sulfuric acid solution as a scrubbing agent.  While it is highly unlikely that sulfuric acid scrubbing agent forms appreciable pure sufuric acid aerosols, the site is reporting sufuric acid aerosols based upon a strict interpretation of the Toxic Chemical Release Inventory Reporting Forms and Instructions (Revised 2012 Version as well as the guidance document "EMERGENCY PLANNING AND COMMUNITY RIGHT-TO-KNOW ACT - SECTION 313 Guidance for Reporting Sulfuric Acid".  The acid is immediately neutralized in the scrubbers or in our wastewater system.  No appreciable sufuric acid aerosols are released to the environment.Based upon the method for estimating acid aerosol generation used for this year's report, the prior year would not exceed the reporting threshold.  The assumption used for estimating acid aerosol generation is that 95% of the aerosols and mists in scrubbers include water and are not pure acid aerosols like the acid aerosol produced by oleum.  Only pure acid aerosol are included in the definition of this TRI chemical.|PRAI:As the macroeconomy improves and with more efficient and cost effective processes, the BASF Seneca  site expects year to year improvement of 5% or more for 2014.|NPYF:Based upon the method for estimating acid aerosol generation used for this year's report, the prior year would not exceed the reporting threshold. The Training Center facility belonged to the U.S. Army from 1942 until 1971 and had an active Skeet Range from approximately 1958 until around 1963 when the U. S. Army allowed the Petaluma Trap and Skeet Club to utilize the Skeet range.  After the U. S. Coast Guard took over the property in mid 1971, the Petaluma Trap and Skeet Club was still granted permission to utilize the range until shooting privileges were suspended in September 2011, and presently remain suspended.  The Petaluma Trap and Skeet Club in the past six (6) years expended an average of 11,697 lbs of lead at the range.	YES	GREGORY.M.HAAS@USCG.MIL			YES

We have traditionally used the number of aircraft serviced to determine the Activity Index which would normally show an accurate ratio.  This year however, we actually increased the number of aircraft serviced but had less fuel and defuel activity.  Normally this Activity Index works but fueling activity can fluctuate depending on customer needs and preference to purchase fuel elsewhere, such as, the airport.  Alot of variables can affect our fuel usage but our customers purchase decision is probably the largest impact.  |PRAI:Based on number of aircraft serviced.	NO	RANDY.ZIMMERMAN@AERO.BOMBARDIER.COM			NO

Submit additional optional information about Other Off-site Transfers, Basis of EstimateBASED ON KNOWLEDGE OF MATERIAL TRANSFERRED OFF-SITE, WEIGHT OF LEAD COMPOUNDS (IN POUNDS) IS 1% OR LESS OF TOTAL WEIGHT SHIPPED/TRANSFERRED.------------------------------------------------------------SECTION 8.11.  Submit additional optional information on source reduction, recycling, or pollution control activities.BASED ON 40 CFR PART 261.4(A)(13), EXCLUDED SCRAP METAL (PROCESSED SCRAP METAL AND UNPROCESSED PROMPT SCRAP METAL) BEING RECYCLED ARE NOT CONSIDERED SOLID WASTES.  "SCRAP METAL" IS DEFINED BY 40 CFR PART 261.1(A)(6) AS BITS AND PIECES OF METAL PARTS (E.G.,) BARS, TURNINGS, RODS, SHEETS, WIRE) OR METAL PIECES THAT MAY BE COMBINED TOGETHER WITH BOLTS OR SOLDERING (E.G., RADIATORS, SCRAP AUTOMOBILES, RAILROAD BOX CARS), WHICH WHEN WORN OR SUPERFLUOUS CAN BE RECYCLED.  AT THE SANTA ROSA LEAD PRODUCTS FACILITY, SCRAP LEAD IS GENERATED IN THE FORM OF SMALL SCRAP SHEETS FROM CUTTING PROCESSES, LEAD DUST FROM GRINDING OPERATIONS, AND EXCESS SOLDER FROM SOLDERING ACTIVITIES.  THIS SCRAP LEAD IS COLLECTED AND CONTAINERIZED IN 55-GALLON METAL CONTAINERS (DRUMS) AND SHIPPED TO THE MAYCO INDUSTRIES FACILITY IN GRANITE CITY, ILLINOIS, AND/OR IS COLLECTED IN "GAYLORD" CRATES AND SHIPPED TO THE MAYCO INDUSTRIES FACILITY IN BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA, WHERE IT IS RE-MELTED/RECYCLED.  THIS CRATED SCRAP LEAD IS ALSO SOLD AS A COMMODITY TO SEVERAL CUSTOMERS.  IN 2012 APPROXIMATELY 45,465 TOTAL POUNDS OF SCRAP LEAD WAS SHIPPED FROM THE SANTA ROSA LEAD PRODUCTS FACILITY: APPROXIMATELY 4,374 POUNDS OF THIS SCRAP LEAD WAS SHIPPED TO THE MAYCO FACILITY IN GRANITE CITY, ILLINOIS, NONE OF THIS SCRAP LEAD WAS SHIPPED TO THE MAYCO FACILITY IN BIRMINGHAM, AL, AND APPROXIMATELY 41,091 POUNDS OF THIS SCRAP LEAD WAS SOLD AS A COMMODITY.|PRAI:CALCULATED BY DIVIDING POUNDS PROCESSED IN RY2012 BY POUNDS PROCESSED IN RY2011.	NO	JEREMY@SANTAROSALEAD.COM			YES

The facility remains compliant with annual production limits also required in the facility air permits that limit VOC emissions to below 19,999 lbs/year.  Conservative estimates for fugitive VOC emissions are used for annual TRI reporting based on an ESTIMATED scrubber capture efficiency of 85%.  Conservative estimates for stack emissions are used for annual TRI reporting based on the permit limit of 98% for scrubber control efficiency.  Actual scrubber control efficiency is 99.8% per a 2005 source test.  In addition, some fugitive emissions are also absorbed into the product and packaging/shipping materials. Martin Co. is a job shop which manufactures a wide range of products for an ever-changing customer base. Because our product mix changes continuously, and the types of metals used to manufacture those products varies accordingly, the amount of chemicals on site may increase or decrease independently of our production ratio. For example, even though our facility's production ratio may increase during a calendar year, the maximum amount of a particular chemical on site at any time may actually decrease because, depending on the product mix, the types of metals processed to manufacture the products in that mix may, overall, contain lower amounts of that chemical. If Marquis Energy were to load out increased quantities of denatured ethanol versus un-denatured ethanol, increased Form R releases would occur or vice versa. 6132WMRQSN11953	1312210506958	000075070	ACETALDEHYDE	TRI	2012	MARQUIS ENERGY LLC	11953 PRAIRIE INDUSTRIAL PKWY	HENNEPIN	PUTNAM	IL	61327	YES	NO	NO	NO								325193						41.276975	-89.31724	783374692										The reduction in potential release from 2011 to 2012 reporting year is due to ongoing and increased operating and maintenance activities resulting in a reduction in leaking components (emissions) identified during LDAR program implementation, and new site-specific emission factors based on 2012 performance testing.  Acetaldehyde is produced during fermentation, and off gases are sent to a CO2 scrubber for removal of acetaldehyde. Sodium bisulfite is injected into the scrubber water to further reduce acetaldehyde emissions. Acetaldehyde within the scrubber liquid stream is recycled back to the cook water tank for use in fermentation. During fermentation, the yeast used to convert the sugar to ethyl alcohol metabolizes the acetaldehyde. Acetaldehyde emissions are also generated during wet feed drying. Emissions are reduced by the thermal oxidizers.	NO	MARKMARQUIS@MARQUISENERGY.COM			NO
